content.en:
In this lesson, you will learn about the following:

  • William Shakespeare
  • the background of the play
  • what tragedy is
  • the themes in the play.
Watch the following video about the life of William Shakespeare before answering the questions that follow.
Check your understanding by answering these multiple-choice questions.
Select the answer you think is correct.

question.en: How many plays is Shakespeare believed to have written?

content.en: The play Macbeth is loosely based on true events in feudal Scotland in the 11th century and would have been known to King James.  King James I of England (also known as James VI of Scotland) inherited the throne through his ancestors Banquo and Fleance who appear in the play.  This violent period in Scotland’s history ended in stronger links with England, much like the union of the crowns that took place when King James became King of England and Scotland. There is a direct reference to King James in the play in Act 4, Scene 1, when Macbeth sees a vision of kings stemming from Banquo’s sons.
King James was fascinated by witchcraft, and it is likely that the witches were included in the play to please him, as Shakespeare wanted his approval.

King James also believed in The Divine Right of Kings, meaning that any attempt to depose a king went directly against God and would be judged harshly. This is reflected in Macbeth’s failure as king. King James’ parents were killed in politically motivated moves to secure power and an attempt was made on his life in the infamous Gunpowder Plot in 1605.

Macbeth and Banquo were real historical figures; however, Shakespeare has manipulated historical facts in order to achieve maximum dramatic impact.  The real Macbeth was not as evil as Shakespeare presents him to be – in fact, he was considered to have been a good king. Likewise, Banquo was historically not as good and innocent as Shakespeare presents him to be. However, as James I was Banquo’s descendant, Shakespeare presents him as a virtuous foil to Macbeth. The characters of Lady Macbeth and the witches are also Shakespeare’s creations and have no basis in history.

The words ‘tragedy’ or ‘tragic’ are often used to describe a sad event or situation. However, in literature, the concept has a different meaning. 

The tragedy is the story in which a hero (usually holding a high and respected position in society) is brought down by their human flaws (called hamartia). These can be ordinary flaws that we can easily identify with, e.g. greed, ambition, pride, and selfishness. 

At the start of any tragedy, we see the hero (or protagonist) at the pinnacle of their career – successful and respected. However, they will have a tragic flaw in their personality that with ultimately lead to their downfall. The plot follows their gradual descent from greatness to destruction and ultimately death. In the end, the hero is isolated from their friends and followers, and we feel a sense of sadness and pity. However, we are appalled by the actions of the hero. The story often acts as a warning for us to guard against the flaws that brought the hero down.

When you have finished reading the play, in your books/on paper/on your device, create a timeline of the events throughout the play to chart Macbeth’s decline and tragic fall from Act 1 to Act 5. 

Click on the icon on the right for some additional hints and support.

hint.en:
You may want to look at the Royal Shakespeare Company’s timeline to help you. 

Timeline

title.en: The main themes of the play

content.en:
Copy this list of the main themes of the play into your book / on paper / onto your device. 

Add quotations that are linked to these themes as you study the play: 

  • Appearance and reality
  • Ambition
  • The supernatural
  • Guilt
  • Violence
  • Kingship/authority
  • Gender
  • Order and disorder
  • Good versus evil.

In your book/on paper/on your device, write down a definition or explanation for each of these words or phrases: 

  • Tragedy
  • Tragic hero
  • Supernatural
  • The Divine Right of Kings
  • The Chain of Being.

Feedback to your teacher.

In this lesson, you will learn about: 

  • Macbeth as a brave warrior 
  • the witches 
  • the prophecies 
  • the reaction of Macbeth and Banquo 
  • Macbeth’s dilemma 
  • Duncan as king.
Read up to Act 1, Scene 4, and/or watch the video clip below.

In Scene 2, we learn about Macbeth’s bravery from the report delivered to King Duncan by a bleeding captain. Macbeth and Banquo have been fighting to defend Scotland from the threat of foreign Norwegian invaders and disloyal Scottish rebels. Macbeth is hailed as the saviour of Scotland and here we see him at the pinnacle of his career – with a glowing reputation and honours from the king.

Copy and complete the table below to help you make notes on the character of Macbeth in this scene.

Quotation Impressions of Macbeth
‘For brave Macbeth --
well he deserves that name--’
‘Disdaining fortune’
‘With his brandish’d steel,
Which smoked with bloody execution’
‘Like valour’s minion’
‘Carved out his passage’
‘he unseam’d him from the nave to the chaps’
‘O valiant cousin!
worthy gentleman!’
‘Bellona’s bridegroom’
‘noble Macbeth’

​What were your preconceived ideas of witches? 

Have your ideas changed since reading the opening scenes? 

Discuss with your classmates.
There are three witches, and they make three prophecies. Three was a number associated with magic during the Jacobean times so the audience would have known that magic and evil was at work.
Write each question in your book, answer them and then share the answers with your teacher.

slides.en: Look at Scene 1 again. What sort of atmosphere is created in this scene? Which words create this atmosphere?
Does this scene give any hint about what might happen later in the play?
Why do you think the witches are waiting for Macbeth?
What do you think the line, ‘Fair is foul and foul is fair’ means?
Which of the play’s themes does the line ‘Fair is foul and foul is fair’ relate to?

content.en:
Macbeth is immediately enraptured by the words of the witches, and it appears that he is more ambitious than we thought. 

Use these quotations to explain what we learn about Macbeth and his attitude from his reactions to the witches.

In contrast, Banquo’s reaction is very different. What do you think Banquo means when he tells Macbeth:

‘And oftentimes, to win us to our harm,
The instruments of darkness tell us truths,
Win us with honest trifles, to betray
In deepest consequence.’

Feedback to the class. Don’t forget to give reasons for your opinions.

Macbeth faces a dilemma. He is intrigued with the thought of the prophecies and becoming king because he is ambitious. However, the thought of what he might have to do in order to take the crown terrifies him.

Read Macbeth’s soliloquy in Scene 3. Track his changing thoughts by completing this table.

Quotation Macbeth’s state of mind
‘This supernatural soliciting
Cannot be ill; cannot be
good’
‘Why hath it given me
earnest of success,
Commencing in a truth?’
‘Whose horrid image
doth unfix my hair
And make my seated
heart knock at my ribs’
‘My thought, whose
murder yet is but
fantastical,
Shakes so my single
state of man’

Click on the icon on the right to complete an extension activity.

extension.en:
When King Duncan publicly names his son, Malcolm, as heir by giving him the title Prince of Cumberland, Macbeth realises there is another obstacle in the way of his ambition. Make a mind map of Macbeth’s reaction to the news. You need to include quotations.  For example:

‘Stars, hide your fires;
Let not light see my black and deep desires.’

content.en:
​In your book / on paper / on your device, summarise the role that Duncan has played so far by making a list of his actions.

Do you think that Duncan is a good king or not?

Organise the points from your list into two columns to help you consider your argument.

In this lesson, you will learn about the following: 

  • the character of Lady Macbeth 
  • how moral is Macbeth? 
  • the ‘persuasion’ scene.
Read up to the end of Act 1 and/or listen to the video below.
We see Lady Macbeth for the first time in Act 1, Scene 5. She is reading a letter from Macbeth telling her about the witches’ prophecies.
Write each of the questions in your book, answer them and then share the answers with your teacher.

slides.en: Macbeth refers to Lady Macbeth as ‘my dearest partner of greatness’. What does this suggest about their relationship?

Lady Macbeth states that Macbeth ‘shalt be what thou art promised’. 

What does this suggest about her character?

Lady Macbeth describes Macbeth as being ‘too full o’ the milk of human kindness’. 

What is she worried about here?

content.en:
Look closely at Lady Macbeth’s soliloquy beginning ‘Come you spirits...’.

In your book / on paper / on your device, copy and complete the following table to help you explain how Shakespeare presents Lady Macbeth in this scene.

Technique Quote Explain what it suggests about Lady Macbeth
Repetition
Imperative/command
Exclamation
Superlative
Use of colour

​How do you think a Jacobean audience would respond to the character of Lady Macbeth? 

Do you think a modern audience would have a different response to her character?  

​Feedback to the class and explain your opinion

When Macbeth arrives home, Lady Macbeth begins to persuade her husband to kill King Duncan so Macbeth can become king. 

In your book / on paper / on your device, write a couple of paragraphs explaining how Lady Macbeth tries to convince Macbeth to carry out the murder. Try to include an explanation of these quotations in your answer:

‘O, never
Shall sun that morrow see!’

‘Your face, my thane, is as a book’

‘Look like the innocent flower,
But be the serpent under‘t.’

‘He that’s coming
Must be provided for’

‘and you shall put
This night’s great business into my
dispatch’

At the start of Scene 7, Macbeth delivers a soliloquy in which he is seen to be full of turmoil and guilt.

In your book / on paper / on your device, make a list of the reasons why Macbeth believes he should not murder Duncan.

What do you think Macbeth should do here?  

Explain your answer.
Act 1, Scene 7 is often referred to as the ‘persuasion’ scene because this is where Lady Macbeth finally succeeds in manipulating Macbeth into committing the murder.

One of Lady Macbeth’s persuasive weapons is her use of rhetorical questions. 

Write down all of the rhetorical questions she uses. 

How does she use each one to manipulate Macbeth?

How do you react to Lady Macbeth’s brutal image of murdering her own child? 

Annotate her speech to help you organise your ideas. 

For example, 'dash’d the brains out' – Lady Macbeth highlights the stark difference between herself and her husband by claiming that she would be prepared to kill her own child. 

Click on the icon on the right for some additional hints and support.

hint.en:
Use this BBC Bitesize resource for further support to analyse the key quotations in this speech. 

BBC Bitesize resource

content.en:
When Lady Macbeth finally wins Macbeth around, she explains the details of the plan. 

Write down these details. 

Do you think it is an effective and foolproof plan? 

Explain why or why not.

​Macbeth and Lady Macbeth appear to be very different characters. In your book / on paper / on your device, create a table like the one below, and make a list of adjectives to describe them in this scene.

Macbeth Lady Macbeth
Doubtful Determined

In this lesson, you will learn about the following: 

  • the contrast between Macbeth and Banquo 
  • the murder of Duncan 
  • how Macbeth and Lady Macbeth react to the murder.
Read Act 2, Scenes 1-2, then watch the videos below.
Select the answer you think is correct.

question.en: What word can Macbeth not say after the murder?

title.en: The contrast between Macbeth and Banquo

content.en:
Look back at Act 2, Scene 1.

What differences do you notice between the characters of Macbeth and Banquo here?

Use the quotations in the table to help you form your opinion.

Banquo Macbeth
‘A heavy summons lies
like lead upon me’		 ‘I think not of them’
‘Restrain in me the
cursed thoughts that
nature
Gives way to in
repose!’ 		‘If you shall cleave
to my consent,
when ‘tis’
‘still keep
My bosom franchised
and allegiance clear.’ 		‘It shall make
honour for you.’
As he prepares to approach Duncan’s chamber, Macbeth is full of guilt and fear. His guilty conscience shows itself in the form of a hallucination of a dagger, directing him to Duncan.

Look at Macbeth’s soliloquy and select five quotations that you think reflect Macbeth’s thoughts and feelings. 

Annotate the quotations in your book / on paper / on your device.

​The audience does not see the actual murder of Duncan. 

Why do you think Shakespeare decided to keep the murder off stage?

title.en: How Macbeth and Lady Macbeth react to the murder

content.en:
Macbeth and Lady Macbeth react to the murder in different ways. At the start of Scene 2, Lady Macbeth is nervous and needs a drink to give her strength and courage. This is the first time we have seen any weakness in her character. 

Macbeth is regretful and full of guilt when he returns with blood-stained hands. However, instead of showing any understanding, Lady Macbeth is contemptuous and mocking of his weaknesses.

Write about how Shakespeare presents Lady Macbeth’s reaction to Macbeth after the murder by considering the following quotations:

‘A foolish thought, to say a sorry sight’

‘Consider it not so deeply’

‘These deeds must not be thought
After these ways; so, it will make us mad.’

‘Go get some water,
And wash this filthy witness from your hand.’

‘Infirm of purpose!’

‘My hands are of your colour; but I shame
To wear a heart so white.’

‘A little water clears us of this deed’

‘How easy is it, then!’

Think about how differently Macbeth reacts to the murder.

Write these quotes in your book / on paper / onto your device, and explain what they suggest about Macbeth’s thoughts and feelings.

‘This is a sorry sight.’

‘I could not say ‘Amen’
When they did say ‘God bless us!’’

‘Macbeth shall sleep no more.’

‘I am afraid to think what I have done’

‘Will all great Neptune’s ocean wash this
blood
Clean from my hand?’

‘To know my deed, t’were best not know
myself.’

​Do you have any sympathy for Macbeth at this point in the play?  

Explain your opinion with reference to events in the play and feedback to your teacher.

Remember to try to use tentative language and analytical verbs like:

  • possibly suggests
  • could imply
  • might infer.

In this lesson, you will learn about: 

  • the disturbance in nature 
  • the discovery of the murder.
Read up to the end of Act 2 and/or listen to the video below before completing the task that follows.
Spot the mistake in the sentence.

question.en: | Lennox | also becomes suspicious and refuses to attend Macbeth’s coronation as king.

content.en:
The Jacobeans believed in the Chain of Being and that the monarch was a direct link between the people and God. Therefore, if a rightful monarch was murdered, the Chain would be broken and there would be turmoil in the country. The night of Duncan’s murder, Nature is thrown into chaos. There is an abnormally fierce storm, earth tremors are felt, tame animals become wild, and small birds kill birds of prey. 

All these events symbolise Macbeth’s reign as one of suffering and disorder.

Macduff discovers Duncan’s murder and is distraught, screaming, ‘O horror, horror, horror!’ 

Each character reacts differently to the discovery of Duncan’s murder. 

In your book / on paper / on your device, write down how Lady Macbeth, Banquo and Macbeth react to the news. Find a quote to support each point.  

Click on the icon on the right for some additional hints and support.

hint.en:
You might choose to use a table to note your quotations and reactions.  

Look at the table below – one quotation has been done for you. Now try to complete the rest of the table.  

CHALLENGE TASK – Can you find three different quotes with slightly different reactions?

content.en:
Macbeth is following Lady Macbeth’s earlier advice and acts in a hypocritical and insincere way.

He makes an emotive speech about his great love for Duncan.

Complete the table below to help you write notes on the effect of the speech.

Quotation Effect
‘Who can be wise, amazed, temperate and furious, loyal and neutral in a moment?’
‘No man’
‘My violent love Outran the pauser, reason’
‘His silver skin laced with his golden blood’
‘His gash’d stabs look’d like a breach in nature’
‘Who could refrain’

​Can you think of two possible reasons why Lady Macbeth faints here?

Malcolm and Donalbain flee in fear for their lives.

Do you think this is the best course of action for them to take? Explain your opinion and feedback to the class.

​Why do you think Macbeth kills the guards? 

What changes have you noticed in Macbeth’s character since the murder of Duncan? 

How has the balance of power shifted in the relationship between Macbeth and Lady Macbeth? 

Feedback to your teacher.

In this lesson, you will learn about: 

  • the relationship between Macbeth and Banquo 
  • the change in Lady Macbeth 
  • the change in Macbeth.
Read up to end of Act 3, Scene 3 and/or watch the videos below, then answer the questions that follow.

activityContent.en:
Banquo feels uneasy and now that Macbeth is king and the prophecies appear to have been fulfilled.

Macbeth asks him to attend a that evening.

Macbeth casually asks where Banquo and his son will go riding that afternoon.

When Banquo has left, Macbeth hires to ambush and kill his best friend and his son.

Macbeth’s motivation is that Banquo’s children will become kings, whilst he and Lady Macbeth are childless.

title.en: The relationship between Macbeth and Banquo

content.en:
The relationship between Macbeth and Banquo changes drastically after hearing the witches’ prophecies. Macbeth is paranoid about the future, and he is becoming trapped in a cycle of murder.

Read Macbeth’s soliloquy that begins ‘To be thus is nothing.’

Consider Macbeth’s thoughts and feelings throughout the soliloquy, and use the table to help you organise your ideas.

‘For Banquo’s issue have I filed my mind;

For them the gracious Duncan have I murder’d’

Quotation Macbeth’s thoughts and feelings
‘To be thus is nothing
But to be safely thus.’
‘There is none but he
Whose being I do fear’
‘Under him,
My Genius is rebuked’
‘Upon my head they
placed a fruitless
crown’
‘And put a barren
sceptre in my gripe,
Thence to be wrench’d
with an unlineal hand’
‘For Banquo’s issue
have I filed my mind;
For them the gracious
Duncan have I
murder’d’

‘Rather than so, come
fate into the list.
And champion me to
the utterance!’

Lady Macbeth is now Queen and has everything she longed for; however, she is not satisfied and is unhappy. When we see her in Act 3, she is very different to the confident character of Acts 1 and 2. Now, she is lonely, disillusioned and full of uncertainty. Yet she masks these feelings in front of Macbeth; this suggests their relationship is deteriorating as they are no longer honest with each other.

Match the quotations below with the correct adjective/phrase describing Lady Macbeth’s thoughts and feelings. 

Now, write a couple of paragraphs about how Shakespeare presents Lady Macbeth in Scene 2, using the table to help you.

title.en: Drag and drop the thoughts and feelings of Lady Macbeth to match the quotations on the left.

text.en: ‘Say to the king, I would attend his leisure    For a few words.’
‘Where our desire is got without content’
‘Tis safer to be that which we destroy’
‘Than by destruction dwell in doubtful joy’
‘Using those thoughts which should indeed have died   With them they think on?’

content.en:
By this stage in the play, Macbeth no longer needs Lady Macbeth in the way he once did. He has become independent and no longer relies on her advice or encouragement. He keeps the planned murder of Banquo a secret from her, either as he no longer needs to share his plans, or because he wants to save her from further guilt and suffering. 

Macbeth is becoming isolated in his own world of murder, deceit, treachery and paranoia and the couple can no longer be open with each other.

Make a mind map to describe Macbeth’s thoughts and feelings in Scene 2.

Use these quotations to help you organise your ideas.

Quotations

‘Why do you keep alone,
Of sorriest fancies your companions making’

‘We have scotch’d the snake, not kill’d it.’

‘better be with the dead,
Whom we, to gain our place, have sent to
peace’

‘Sleek o’er your rugged looks’

‘We must… make our faces vizards to our
hearts.’

‘O, full of scorpions is my mind’

‘There shall be done
A deed of dreadful note.’

‘Come, seeling night,
Scarf up the tender eye of pitiful day.’

'Things bad begun make strong themselves
by ill.'

​Macbeth and Lady Macbeth have gained a hollow victory as neither one seems happy. 

What message do you think Shakespeare is giving the audience about ambition and greed? 

Feedback to the class.

​Are your feelings about Macbeth and Lady Macbeth beginning to change? 

Do you feel any sympathy for either of them?

In this lesson, you will learn about: 

  • Banquo’s ghost 
  • the relationship between Macbeth and Lady Macbeth 
  • the suffering of Scotland.

Act 3, Scene 4 is the banquet scene where Macbeth and Lady Macbeth should feel triumphant as it is their first public celebration in their new positions. However, Macbeth is wracked with guilt over the murder of Banquo and as a result, has a hallucination of Banquo’s ghost at the feast. Macbeth is the only one who can see the apparition and the scene soon falls into chaos and disorder.
Write each of the questions in your book, answer them and then share the answers with your teacher.

slides.en: How many injuries did Banquo sustain on his head?
What excuse did Lady Macbeth make for her husband’s behaviour?
Which lord did not attend the banquet?
Why does Macbeth decide to visit the witches?
What is the name of the English king who is helping Malcolm?

content.en: It is after seeing Banquo’s ghost that Macbeth’s character begins to deteriorate rapidly into further evil. The ghost is the outward manifestation of Macbeth’s guilt – just like the ‘air drawn dagger’. After this scene, Macbeth descends into senseless slaughter and tyranny.

Upon hearing about Fleance’s escape, Macbeth says:

‘Then comes my fit again: I had else been
perfect,
Whole as the marble, founded as the rock,
But now I am cabin’d, cribb’d, confined, bound
in
To saucy doubts and fears.’

Annotate this quotation, focusing on single words and their connotations to help explore meaning.

Analyse these quotations to help you write about Macbeth’s thoughts and feelings in this scene.

‘Which of you have done this?’

‘Thou canst not say I did it: never shake
Thy gory locks at me.’

‘Ay, and a bold one, that dare look on that
Which might appall the devil.’

‘Prithee, see there! behold! look! lo! how say
you?’

‘Avaunt! and quit my sight! let the earth hide
thee!’

‘Thy bones are marrowless, thy blood is cold’

‘Take any shape but that, and my firm nerves
Shall never tremble’

‘It will have blood; they say, blood will have
blood’

At the end of the scene, Macbeth makes some ominous and sinister comments about his future actions: 

  • ‘I am in blood Stepp’d in so far that, should I wade no more, Returning were as tedious as go o’er’
  • ‘We are yet but young in deed.’

Consider these two quotations and explain what you think Macbeth means. 

Feedback to your teacher.

title.en: The relationship between Macbeth and Lady Macbeth

content.en: This is the last time we see Macbeth and Lady Macbeth together as a couple and the last time we see Lady Macbeth sane. The growing distance between them is noticeable at the start as Lady Macbeth keeps her distance, ‘keeping her state.’ However, she still tries to protect and save Macbeth’s position when she sees his irrational behaviour.

Re-read the scene carefully and consider what aspects of Lady Macbeth’s character are still present.

Use these quotations as a starting point for your notes.

‘My royal lord,You do not give the cheer’

‘my lord is often thus, And hath been from his youth: pray you, keep seat’

‘Are you a man?’

‘O proper stuff! This is the very painting of your fear’

‘What, quite unmann’d in folly’

‘You have… broke the good meeting, With most admired disorder.’

‘Stand not upon the order of your going, But go at once.’

Click on the icon on the right to complete an extension activity.

extension.en:
At the end of the scene, an exhausted Lady Macbeth says to Macbeth, ‘you lack the season of all natures, sleep’. 

Why might this line be considered ironic?

content.en:
Speculation and suspicion about Macbeth’s actions are sweeping across Scotland. Macbeth has lost his reputation as noble and worthy and instead is described in fearful terms. 

Click on the icon on the right to complete an extension activity.

extension.en:
Scotland is now described as a ‘suffering country under a hand accursed’. 

How does this compare to when Duncan was king?

content.en:
Macbeth is described as a ‘tyrant’ twice in four lines. 

What does this suggest about the change in his character?

In this lesson, you will learn about: 

  • Macbeth’s visit to the witches 
  • the murder of Macduff’s family.

Read up to the end of Act 4, Scene 2 and/or watch the video clips below. 

Then answer the questions that follow.
Select the answer you think is correct.
content.cy: Dewiswch bob ateb sy’n gywir, yn eich barn chi.

question.en: How many apparitions do the witches show Macbeth?

content.en: Select the answer you think is correct.
content.cy: Dewiswch bob ateb sy’n gywir, yn eich barn chi.

question.en: What does Macbeth do when he hears Macduff has fled to England?

answer.en: He arranges for Macduff’s family to be killed
He talks to Malcolm about Macduff

content.en: Select the answer you think is correct.
content.cy: Dewiswch bob ateb sy’n gywir, yn eich barn chi.

question.en: Who does Lady Macduff question about her husband’s flight before she tries to explain the situation to her son?

title.en: Macbeth goes back to see the witches

content.en:
The fact that Macbeth actively seeks out the witches shows how reliant he is becoming on the prophecies, and how he has lost his sense of morality.  

He is commanding and arrogant when speaking to the witches, calling them ‘black and midnight hags.’ He is so desperate to find out his fate that he doesn’t care if disorder and chaos follow –  

‘Even till destruction sicken; answer me To what I ask you’.

The witches conjure three apparitions for Macbeth. 

In your book / on paper / on your device, make a list of the apparitions and what they tell Macbeth. 

Click on the icon on the right for some additional hints and support.

hint.en:
These are the three apparitions: an armed head; a bloody child; and a child crowned, with a tree in his hand.

What they might suggest about Macbeth:

  • the head – Macbeth himself. When? How?
  • the child – Macbeth’s naivety. Why?
  • the child crowned – Malcolm and the army coming from Birnam Wood. How? Who is the child who is going to be crowned as king?

content.en: Macbeth takes the prophecies without question and again feels jubilant and confident. However, he is still obsessed and tormented as to whether ‘Banquo’s issue shall ever reign in this kingdom’. The witches show Macbeth a long line of kings descended from Banquo.

After he leaves the witches, we see that Macbeth is becoming more brutal and plans to murder Macduff and his family.

Track the development of Macbeth’s character by analysing these quotations.

‘The very firstlings of my heart shall be
The firstlings of my hand.’

‘give to the edge o’ the sword
His wife, his babes, and all unfortunate souls
That trace him in his line.’

‘This deed I’ll do before this purpose cool.’
Macduff has left his wife and children and has fled to England to join Malcolm in gathering forces to march against Macbeth.

What differences do you notice between the characters of Lady Macduff and Lady Macbeth and how they are presented? 

Make a list of the differences in your book / on paper / on your device. 

Share and discuss your findings with the class.

​Why do you think Shakespeare shows the murder of Macduff’s son on stage?

How would an audience react to this?

Do you think Macduff did the right thing in leaving Scotland? Explain your opinion and feedback to your teacher.

In this lesson, you will learn about: 

  • the state of Scotland 
  • Macduff’s reaction to the murder of his family 
  • the character of Malcolm.

Read to the end of Act 4.  

This is the first time we have seen Malcolm since he and his brother fled after their father’s murder. At the start of the scene, he tests Macduff’s loyalty by pretending to be even more evil than Macbeth. Macduff passes the test and Malcolm is convinced by his honourable intentions.

Analyse these quotations, which show the suffering of Scotland in emotive terms, and explain what they tell the audience about the state of the country under Macbeth’s tyranny.

Quotation Effect
‘down-fall’n
birthdom’
‘Each new morn
New widows howl,
new orphans cry’
‘New sorrows
Strike heaven on the
face’
‘our country sinks
beneath the yoke’
‘It weeps, it bleeds’
‘Each new day a gash
Is added to her
wounds’
‘Alas, poor country!’
‘It cannot
Be call’d our mother,
but our grave… and
shrieks that rend the
air
Are made, not
mark’d’
‘good men’s lives
Expire before the
flowers in their caps’

title.en: Macduff’s reaction to the murder of his family

content.en: Macduff is understandably distraught upon learning of the murder of his family. He blames himself for leaving them unprotected and calls himself ‘sinful Macduff’ as he is full of guilt.

Look closely at Macduff’s reaction to the news.

Analyse and explain how Macduff is presented through these quotations.

‘My children too?’

‘And I must be from thence!
My wife kill’d too?’

‘He has no children.’

‘All my pretty ones? Did you say all?’

‘All?
What, all my pretty chickens and their dam
At one fell swoop?’

‘front to front
Bring thou this fiend of Scotland and myself’

Malcolm is presented as a strong-minded leader who is also capable of showing sympathy and compassion as seen in his response to Macduff’s grief. He encourages Macduff to allow himself to feel grief to prevent his heart from breaking. This compassion is a stark contrast to Macbeth’s brutality.

Make notes on the character of Malcolm, using these quotations as a starting point.

‘Give sorrow words’

‘the grief that does not speak
Whispers the o’er-fraught heart’

‘Let’s make us medicines of our great
revenge,
To cure this deadly grief.’

‘Be this the whetstone of your sword: let grief
Convert to anger; blunt not the heart, enrage
it.’

‘Macbeth
Is ripe for shaking’

Duncan put ‘his absolute trust’ in others, only to be betrayed. 

What differences do you notice between Malcolm and his father, Duncan? 

Do you think Malcolm will be a good king? Explain your opinion by giving reasons and feedback to the class.

In pairs, look at the way Macbeth is presented in these quotations: 

  • ‘Devilish Macbeth’
  • ‘Black Macbeth’
  • ‘This tyrant whose sole name blisters our tongue’
  • ‘Hell-kite’
  • ‘Fiend of Scotland’

How does this impression of Macbeth compare with earlier impressions of him in the play? Don’t forget to use tentative language and analytical verbs such as ‘possibly infers’, ‘could suggest’, ‘maybe implies’, etc.  

Feedback to the class.

In this lesson, you will learn about: 

  • the change in Lady Macbeth’s character 
  • Macbeth’s growing isolation.

Read up to end of Act 5, Scene 4. 

Now watch the summary video below.

Act 5, Scene 1 is the last time we see Lady Macbeth. By this point, she is unable to sleep, and lives in the frightening world of her guilt and regret. Whilst sleepwalking, she obsessively tries to remove an imaginary spot of blood from her hands. The blood is a symbol of her guilt from which she will never be free.

activityContent.en:
Lady Macbeth speaks in , not verse, to reflect her insanity.

Lady Macbeth needs to have with her at all times because she is terrified of darkness and hell.

Lady Macbeth rubs her hands for a

‘All the perfumes of ’ will not sweeten her little hand.

The nursery rhyme rhythm in her words ‘The Thane of had a wife’ makes the scene even more chilling.

content.en:
Produce a mind map to represent Lady Macbeth’s thoughts and feelings in this scene.

Analyse these quotations to help organise your ideas.

‘Out, damned spot! out I say!’

‘Hell is murky!’

‘Fie, my
Lord, fie! a soldier and, afeared?’

‘who would have thought the old man to
have had so much blood in him.’

‘What, will these hands ne’er be clean?’

‘What's
done cannot be undone.’

Click on the icon on the right to complete an extension activity.

extension.en: How much sympathy do you have for Lady Macbeth at this stage in the play? Give reasons for your opinion.

content.en:
Macbeth is becoming increasingly desperate as his followers are leaving him. He has lost control and has no one to confide in, trusting and pathetically holding on to the prophecies.

The Lords have nothing but disdain and contempt for him.

Annotate these quotations to help you remember them.

‘He cannot buckle his distemper’d cause
Within the belt of rule.’

‘now does he feel his title
Hang loose about him, like a giant’s robe
Upon a dwarfish thief.’

‘Meet we the medicine of the sickly weal’

Click on the icon on the right to complete an extension activity.

extension.en:
Images of medicine and healing are used to describe Malcom, whilst Macbeth is associated with images of disease. 

Why do you think Shakespeare does this? 

Note some of the images used for Malcom and Macbeth and explore their significance.

content.en:
In this lesson, you will learn about: 

  • Macbeth’s reaction to Lady Macbeth’s death 
  • Macbeth’s last stand 
  • the restoration of order.

title.en: Macbeth’s reaction to Lady Macbeth’s death

content.en: Read to the end of the play, then watch the video below of the last scenes.

The death of Lady Macbeth takes place off stage and is reported to Macbeth. By this point, Macbeth is numbed because of all the horrors he has committed. He accepts her death calmly, saying – 

‘She should have died hereafter;
There would have been a time for such a word.’

Look closely at Macbeth’s soliloquy.

Note how Macbeth’s thoughts and feelings are presented here.

Analyse these quotations as a starting point.

‘To-morrow, and to-morrow, and to-morrow’

‘And all our yesterdays have lighted fools
The way to dusty death.’

‘Out, out, brief candle’

‘Life’s but a walking shadow, a poor player
That struts and frets his hour upon the stage’

‘it is a tale
Told by an idiot, full of sound and fury,
Signifying nothing.’

Macbeth decides to fight to the end, despite being outnumbered by the army of Malcolm and Macduff. He stills clings desperately to the prophecy that ‘no one born of woman’ shall harm him. Although life has become meaningless to him, he would rather kill than be killed –

‘whiles I see lives, the gashes
 Do better upon them.’

When Macbeth comes face-to-face with Macduff, he seems to show some remorse for slaughtering his family.

Look at the quotations used by each character here.

Analyse what the quotations suggest about their thoughts and feelings.

Macbeth Macduff
‘my soul is too much
charged
With blood of thine
already.’ 		‘Turn, hell-hound,
turn!’
‘I bear a charmed life’ ‘My voice is in my
sword’ ’
‘Be these juggling
fiends no more
believed,
That palter with us in
a double sense’ 		‘thou bloodier villain
Than terms can give
thee out!’
‘I’ll not fight with
thee’ 		‘Then yield thee,
coward’
‘I will not yield,
To kiss the ground
before young
Malcolm’s feet’ 		‘We’ll have thee, as
our rarer monster
are,
Painted on a pole’

Click on the icon on the right to complete an extension activity.

extension.en: Explain how Macbeth was tricked by each of the witches’ prophecies.

content.en: With the death of Macbeth, Malcolm is proclaimed as the rightful king of Scotland and The Chain of Being is restored.

Look at Macbeth’s final speech.

In your books / on paper / on your device, answer the following question.

How does Shakespeare convince the audience that Malcolm will bring peace and order to Scotland?

Share your work with your teacher.

​In his speech, Malcolm refers to Macbeth and Lady Macbeth as ‘this dead butcher and his fiend-like queen’. 

To what extent do you think this is a fair description? 

Discuss and feedback to the class, giving reasons for your ideas and opinions.

In this lesson, you will learn about the following: 

  • the assessment objectives 
  • how to prepare for your NEA 
  • how to organise a response.

The term 'assessment objectives’ simply refers to what your teacher will be looking for in your answer.

AO1 – Respond to texts critically and imaginatively; select and evaluate relevant textual detail to illustrate and support interpretations. 

In simple terms, this means: 

  • How well do you know the events of the play?
  • Can you show understanding of characters and relationships?
  • Can you use evidence and/or quotations to prove your points?

AO2 – Explain how language, structure and form contribute to writers’ presentation of ideas, themes and settings. 

In simple terms, this means: 

  • Can you explain and analyse the effects of words and images?
  • Can you explain why Shakespeare chose to use certain words?
  • Can you explain how a word/image creates a particular mood/atmosphere?

Download the mark scheme below.  

In pairs, read the mark scheme and discuss any words/phrases that are unclear or unfamiliar.  

Feedback to the class.

title.en: How to prepare for your NEA

content.en:
• Make sure you understand the events of the play. 
  • Check your understanding of the main characters and their relationships. 
  • Include relevant quotations and evidence in your response. 
  • Watch different performances of key scenes to develop your understanding of the characters. 
  • Use the knowledge organiser available below to help you.

Every year, WJEC sets questions based on different themes for students to answer.  

Example theme: the presentation of male characters. 

Example NEA title: 

Macbeth is presented as an ambitious character. Referring closely to what he says and does, discuss the way he behaves in the play.

Consider which aspects of the character and which relevant scenes you want to focus on. 

For example, you might want to think about making notes on the following: 

  • how Macbeth is presented at the start of the play 
  • Macbeth’s relationship with Lady Macbeth 
  • the murders of Duncan and Banquo 
  • how Macbeth is presented at the end of the play.

Decide which quotations you want to use to prove your points. 

Remember that using short, integrated quotations is more effective than writing out large chunks of text.

Example theme: Courage   

Possible NEA title:  

‘Macbeth displays courage throughout the play.’ To what extent do you agree with this statement?

You may want to consider making notes on the following: 

  • How is Macbeth presented at the beginning of the play? 
  • Which examples of his behaviour would you include? 
  • How is he described by different characters? 
  • Which quotations would you use? 
  • What sort of conversations does he have with Lady Macbeth?  
  • Which examples would you select? 
  • When is he courageous? 
  • How does Lady Macbeth manipulate him? 
  • What is his behaviour like after the murders of Duncan, Banquo and Macduff’s family? 
  • What is his behaviour like at the banquet? 
  • How does Macbeth behave at the end? 
  • Is he presented as courageous in Act 5?

Note three things that you’ve learned in this lesson about writing your NEA.   

Note two things you need to do to improve or find out about before writing your NEA.  

 Write one question to ask your teacher.
